attributes.title: To Stay or to Leave? Explaining Migration Decisions in Islamic State-Controlled Mosul

q1.value: To Stay or to Leave? Explaining Migration Decisions in Islamic State-Controlled Mosul

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: What are the conditions under which civilians living in territory captured by an insurgent group will prefer its system of "rebel governance" to that of the incumbent state (Arjona 2016; Mampilly 2011)? Given the opportunity to flee to government-controlled areas, IDP camps, or neighboring countries, why do some people stay? This paper uses the case of the Islamic State’s three-year rule over the Iraqi city of Mosul to explore the individual-level motivations--social, political, economic, and ideological--that influence the decisions of potential migrants to stay or leave territory captured by a state-building insurgent group. Through a survey of 1,400 residents of Mosul, I compare and contrast the motivations of "stayers" (those who remained in Mosul after IS's arrival in June 2014) and "leavers" (those who fled Mosul in the early days of IS rule and have since returned to the city). While recognizing that decisions to stay or leave are multi-factorial, I develop and test a discrete-choice theory of migration hypothesizing that civilians who had previously experienced high levels of injustice in their interactions with Iraqi state authorities--for example, bribery, sectarian discrimination, and police harassment--were more likely to be "stayers" than those with fewer or no such grievances. If this hypothesis is supported by the data, it would suggest that weak rule of law in Iraq contributed to civilian cooperation with and support for IS. The survey will also assess several alternative explanations that could explain migration decisions: economic resources, social networks, information, threat perceptions, and ideology.

q27.value: IIACSS (Independent Institute for Administration and Civil Society Studies)

attributes.title: Impact Evaluation of REDD+ Programme in Sierra Leone

q1.value: Impact Evaluation of REDD+ Programme in Sierra Leone

q2.value: Mandy Malan | Elisabeth Gsottbauer | Paul Hofman | Tom Swinfield | Andreas Kontoleon | Maarten Voors

q5.value: Thanks to Gola Rainforest Conservation and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds for their input and cooperation in this study. Thanks to Tara Slough for the power calculations and parallel trends code. Thanks also to Rachel Carmenta.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Few papers have rigorously examined the impact of conservation programs on economic and conservation. Indeed, within conservation science there are calls for increasing the number of impact evaluations of conservation projects. In this study we assess the five year impact of the REDD+ programme implemented in Eastern Sierra Leone in communities around the Gola Rainforest National Park. REDD+ (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation) programmes aim to reduce tropical deforestation, thereby increasing carbon sequestration and mitigating climate change. In addition, the National Park has been classified as one of the 34 most important biodiversity hotspots in the world. The REDD+ programme in Sierra Leone has been implemented from 2014 by Gola Rainforest Conservation (GRC) and provides direct social benefits to Forest Edge Communities (FECs). The Gola REDD+ project’s overarching objectives are to increase food security and income and generate support for conservation of the GRNP. Activities include agricultural trainings, the establishment of savings and loans association, and specific programs for the major cash crop cocoa. With data collected in multiple waves, we can estimate the treatment effect of these activities through difference-in-difference analysis. By assessing how these programs affected economic outcomes as well as conservation outcomes, this research will contribute to the ongoing debate on whether conservation and poverty reduction can go hand in hand.

q16.value: The impact of the REDD+ programme on three families: Economic outcomes, Conservation Attitudes and Conservation Behaviour. Each family consists of several outcomes. For economic outcomes: Income, Assets, Durable loans and Resilience. For conservation attitudes: conservation attitudes, awareness of conservation norms, sustainable farming practices, human wildlife conflict perceptions. For conservation behaviour: forest loss, primary forest loss, secondary forest loss. We also have several secondary outcomes (see PAP).

q17.value: To estimate the average treatment effect we estimate a standard Difference-in-Difference model. This is possible because we have data from 2014, before the REDD+ project was implemented, as well as data from 2019. This estimator gets us an unbiased estimate of the treatment effect, if we can assume that without the project, the villages would have trended similarly (parallel trends assumption). As we have data from 2010 we can check if at least prior to the REDD+ project trends in (future) REDD+ and non-REDD+ villages are parallel, which would make it likely they would be parallel afterwards.

q21.value: No, but the pre-analysis plan does contain a prospective power analysis

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Does providing district-level public opinion polling increase the likelihood a legislator will vote with their constituents? Does this effect depend on an accountability mechanism of also sharing this information with a local media outlet?

q16.value: Does providing district-level public opinion polling increase the likelihood a legislator will vote with their constituents? Does this effect depend on an accountability mechanism of also sharing this information with a local media outlet?

q17.value: We will investigate treatment effects on vote cast on the bill. All treatment effects will be intent-to-treat analysis. We will analyze data using randomization inference using ri2 in R. We will report both the difference-in-means and a covariate-adjusted estimate using the covariates from the above balance check. The randomization inference will take into account the blocking. We will run 10,000 simulations. We will report one-tailed significance tests. In all districts, an overwhelming majority supports the bill, thus we expect the treatments will only increase the likelihood a legislator supports the bill.

In all districts, an overwhelming majority supports the bill, thus we expect the treatments will only increase the likelihood a legislator supports the bill.

attributes.title: Keeping up with the Joneses? Evidence on indirect mobilization effects from a partisan GOTV experiment

q1.value: Keeping up with the Joneses? Evidence on indirect mobilization effects from a partisan GOTV experiment

q2.value: Florian Foos | Peter John | Christian Mueller

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: There is surprisingly little causally-identified evidence for the existence of turnout spillovers between neighbours, raising questions about whether between-household in- fluence can explain correlated turnout behaviour within neighbourhoods. From a the- oretical perspective, competition mechanisms would lead us to expect that households mobilize to “keep up” with their neighbours, and especially so if conflicting party af- filiations induce further elements of political competition. To test this theory, we use data on households excluded pre-random assignment from a partisan GOTV experi- ment that we previously conducted in collaboration with the UK Labour Party. We compare the turnout rates of non-experimental households in streets assigned to treat- ment to the turnout rates of non-experimental households in streets assigned to control. Moreover, using geo-coding, we investigate whether treatment effects vary conditional on the distance to the closest household, and conditional on whether the members of this closest household support the same or a rival party.

q16.value: Street-level hypotheses: • H1 - one-sided hypothesis: Neighbourhood effects hypothesis : Subjects living in non-experimental households in treated streets are more likely to turn out than subjects living in non-experimental households in control streets. • H2: Partisan mobilization hypothesis : The more politically heteroge- neous the street, the weaker the spillover effects between experimental and non-experimental households. • H3: Partisan competition hypothesis : The more politically heteroge- neous the street, the stronger the spillover effects between experimental and non-experimental households. Household-level hypotheses: • H4 - one-sided hypothesis: Neighbourhood effects hypothesis : The closer the distance between non-experimental households and exper- imental households in treated streets, the more likely subjects living in 4 non-experimental households are to turn out compared to non-experimental households living at the same distance to experimental-households in control streets. • H5: Partisan mobilization hypothesis : The closer the distance be- tween non-experimental households and experimental households of the same partisan identity in treated streets, the more likely subjects living in non-experimental households are to turn out compared to non-experimental households living at the same distance to experimental-households in control streets. • H6: Partisan competition hypothesis : The closer the distance be- tween non-experimental households and experimental households of a ri- val partisan identity in treated streets, the more likely subjects living in non-experimental households are to turn out compared to non-experimental households living at the same distance to experimental-households in control streets.

q17.value: Linear models, clustering standard errors at the level of assignment, the street level (see PAP)

registration_responses.q1: Keeping up with the Joneses? Evidence on indirect mobilization effects from a partisan GOTV experiment
registration_responses.q2: Florian Foos | Peter John | Christian Mueller

attributes.title: Higher Education and Democracy: Elite Views on Education-Based Descriptive Representation

q1.value: Higher Education and Democracy: Elite Views on Education-Based Descriptive Representation

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The aim of this study is to learn more about what elected (political) representatives believe leads a representative body to perform better: a higher level of educational background among representatives or a better reflection of the educational background among citizens (i.e. 'descriptive representation'). Moreover, we are interested in the role of representatives' capacity to communicate complex matters, as well as the possession of specific knowledge.

q16.value: We expect that, as a general pattern, elected representatives assess the performance of a representational body to be higher when the educational profile of councilors and citizens match. Moreover, we expect that those who find the ability to communicate well and possess specific knowledge more important, will expect a representative body to perform less well in the case of an educational mismatch.

q17.value: We conducted an experiment, and included a number of questions in the first wave of the Panel of Elected Representatives (PER), a repeated web-based survey among elected representatives in Norway. All representatives (municipal, county, national levels, as well as the Sami parliament) were invited to take part. The response rate was over 35%, resulting in an estimated 4200 respondents. The data will be released on 04 May 2018.

q23.value: The designs have been reviewed and ethics approved by the scientific committee of the Panel of Elected Representatives (PER)

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

All representatives (municipal, county, national levels, as well as the Sami parliament) were invited to take part. The response rate was over 35%, resulting in an estimated 4200 respondents. The data will be released on 04 May 2018.
registration_responses.q23: The designs have been reviewed and ethics approved by the scientific committee of the Panel of Elected Representatives (PER)

q5.value: The authors would like to thank Adria Lawrence, Lauren MacLean, Sarah Parkinson, Tom Pepinsky, Ben Read, and Elisabeth Wood for their helpful feedback and comments for feedback on the survey design and implementation.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Many political scientists conduct fieldwork in challenging places such as weak, post-conflict, hybrid, or authoritarian regions, or research contentious topics in democracies. Conducting fieldwork in the profession of political science has become increasingly common for not only comparative politics scholars but also international relations scholars. While there is minimal systematic information about those who engage in fieldwork , there is an increasing interest in documenting the logistical and security considerations political scientists face during fieldwork, the ethical challenges of doing fieldwork in conflict zones, and the challenges of obtaining quantitative data from fieldwork . Moreover, we believe that there might be particular differences in these answers based on demographic characteristics. How do challenges (and opportunities) faced during fieldwork vary by sex, race, age, and rank? While there exist many anecdotal reflections on the impact of these identities on the fieldwork experience, there exists little systematic data. Using a survey of all assistant, associate, and full professors in international relations and comparative politics from the top 60 research universities (R1s) and top 25 liberal arts colleges (LACs) in the United States, we assess how these demographic characteristics impact the main challenges posed during fieldwork, including, sexual harassment, secondary trauma, safety, and discrimination. The results can be used to help researchers better prepare for the challenges of doing fieldwork in particular, become better prepared to deal with logistical challenges, threats to physical security, sexual harassment, as well as brainstorm how to deal with psychological and ethical challenges when conducting fieldwork in contentious areas or on contentious topics.

q16.value: We will evaluate the how sex, age, rank, current institution (teaching or R1 as well as top ten versus all other schools), graduate school, subfield, and main methodological orientation affect the following: " Participation in fieldwork " Prior fieldwork experience " Fieldwork preparation " Methods applied in the field " Length of stay in the field " Obligations at home " Financing of fieldwork " Work with vulnerable populations " Work in dangerous locations " Benefits received from doing fieldwork " Setback experienced from doing fieldwork " Difficulty accessing research subjects " Experience of shocks and management of shocks " Feeling threatened " Views about working in dangerous locations " Importance of fieldwork in the discipline We will also assess how answers to some questions differ based on experience with fieldwork-comparing answers between those who have engaged in fieldwork and those who have not. In particular, we expect there to be differences in answers on the questions related to views about working in dangerous locations, obligations at home, and importance of fieldwork in the discipline. In the appendix, we will provide information about whether those that engage in fieldwork systematically differ from those that do not. Our main hypothesis is that we will find gendered differences on some of the above-mentioned questions. However, we expect to find differences based on the above mentioned pre-specified variables as well. We will report all findings on these topics in the publications whether in the main paper or the appendix. We will include both bivariate regression analysis and multivariate analysis as well, which will include the variables mentioned above.

q17.value: To undertake the project, we intend to send out a survey to all assistant, associate, and full professors in international relations and comparative politics from the top 60 R1 universities and top 25 liberal arts colleges in the United States (based on the 2017 U.S. News and World Report rankings). This leads to a total of 1132 people in the sample. We hope for at least a response rate of at least 20% (a response by 225 people). We will look for systematic bias between responders and non-responders by comparing data on sex, current employer, sub-field, rank, and personal connection to the PIs. This will give us an idea of the people that were most likely to respond. We will also use data from the TRIP data to compare our sample to a general IR sample globally.

registration_responses.q5: The authors would like to thank Adria Lawrence, Lauren MacLean, Sarah Parkinson, Tom Pepinsky, Ben Read, and Elisabeth Wood for their helpful feedback and comments for feedback on the survey design and implementation.

attributes.title: Affective Judgements and the Misattribution of Responsibility for the Economy

q1.value: Affective Judgements and the Misattribution of Responsibility for the Economy

q9.value: Study will conducted over a few weeks. At the point of registration less than 5% of the target number of subjects were recruited, assigned to treatment, and completed the survey.

q15.value: This Pre-Analysis Plan (PAP) is for a simple survey-experiment designed to examine whether affective judgements of leaders limit individuals' capacity to process relevant information about their competence. The proposed experiment complements previous studies that we conducted over the past few years. In these studies, we treated individuals with information about countries' relative performance and about exogenous economic shocks and observed whether this affected their assessment of incumbent competence. The rationale of these experiments is straightforward. If we accept that countries' economic performance results from some measure of government merit (policymaking) and luck (exogenous conditions), it follows that individuals need to discount luck to assess competence based on the outcomes they observe. One caveat in these studies is that in all of them participants were asked to evaluate the competence of real-world presidents that had been governing for a few years. We now test whether individuals behave in the same way when evaluating hypothestical presidents. The rationale behind this approach is that individuals cannot be affectively linked to individuals that do not exist, and about whom very little information is provided. As a result, we can examine whether with this blank affective slate, individuals do adjust their assessments using appropriate information ``correctly.''

q16.value: The main hypothesis is that correct reassessments of presidents based on “additional relevant information” we be more likely in individuals who cannot have affective judgements of the presidents being evaluated. In the pre-analysis plan we detail exactly the parameters being estimated.

q17.value: The PAP presents details of the main hypothesis and several heterogeneous effects of interest. The main analysis will be based on simple comparisons between the group formed by those who are told they are evaluating former-president Lula, and a control group who is evaluating a hypothetical president.

q19.value: Per our PAP, we will collect data on 1080 attentive respondents (those who pass the attention screener). We estimate this will require around 2200 total respondents.

attributes.title: Foreign Aid's Impact on the Demand Side of Civil Society

q1.value: Foreign Aid's Impact on the Demand Side of Civil Society

q5.value: I would like to thank Lucy Martin, Graeme Robertson, Sean Norton, Brian Overington, Cole Harvey, Silviya Nitsova, and Jacob Smith for their feedback and advice on this project and pre-analysis plan.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan presents a study that seeks to identify how citizens of countries with a history of foreign support for their civil societies relate to civil society organizations that are foreign in a variety of ways. Civil society has been theorized as being a crucial component of democracy and a crucial actor in democratic and economic development. However, we do not know how citizen attitudes toward civil society may have been altered by foreign aid. The democracy assistance literature has looked at the impact of donor preferences and funding patterns on nongovernmental organizations in recipient countries --- the supply side of foreign aid. A significant interest of the foreign aid literature has been to investigate the relationship between citizens’ views of their government’s legitimacy and the receipt of foreign aid, pulling into focus the impact of foreign aid on the demand side in terms of governance. This project seeks to unite these two strands of the literature by turning to the demand side of civil society, and how it is impacted by foreign aid. I posit that the more foreign aid recipients perceive a civil society organization as being, the less likely they will be to want to engage directly with it, although they may expect the organization itself to be better suited to bringing developments to their community. I test this theory using a conjoint survey experiment carried out on Malawian market vendors who are the target of a large-scale USAID intervention. The findings will have important implications for how foreign aid might impact citizen engagement in a way that has not been captured before.

q16.value: The more foreign an organization, the more likely an individual will be to assess the organization positively. At the same time, the more foreign an organization, the less likely an individual will be to express a desire to interact with that organization actively. An organization that is more foreign along multiple dimensions will seem particularly foreign to individuals, and therefore the interaction between different organization characteristics will sharpen the effects in the previous hypothesis. Individuals who are already in community organizations will be less likely to want to participate in more foreign organizations, and their evaluations of foreign organizations will be lower. Individuals who demonstrate apathy about their own role in achieving desirable outcomes because of the work that other, non-local organizations do on their behalf will as a whole be more ambivalent about engagement with organizations. These individuals will be more likely to see more foreign organizations as being of higher quality.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested via a conjoint survey experiment. Analysis of the conjoint will be done via logit and OLS. A causal ANOVA estimator developed by Egami and Imai (2018) will be used to test for interaction effects. Subgroup analysis based on respondents’ answers to two different survey questions will be done as well. Please see pre-analysis plan for more details.

q24.value: 18-2303; Office of Human Research Ethics – University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

registration_responses.q1: Foreign Aid's Impact on the Demand Side of Civil Society
registration_responses.q5: I would like to thank Lucy Martin, Graeme Robertson, Sean Norton, Brian Overington, Cole Harvey, Silviya Nitsova, and Jacob Smith for their feedback and advice on this project and pre-analysis plan.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: This pre-analysis plan presents a study that seeks to identify how citizens of countries with a history of foreign support for their civil societies relate to civil society organizations that are foreign in a variety of ways. Civil society has been theorized as being a crucial component of democracy and a crucial actor in democratic and economic development. However, we do not know how citizen attitudes toward civil society may have been altered by foreign aid. The democracy assistance literature has looked at the impact of donor preferences and funding patterns on nongovernmental organizations in recipient countries --- the supply side of foreign aid. A significant interest of the foreign aid literature has been to investigate the relationship between citizens’ views of their government’s legitimacy and the receipt of foreign aid, pulling into focus the impact of foreign aid on the demand side in terms of governance. This project seeks to unite these two strands of the literature by turning to the demand side of civil society, and how it is impacted by foreign aid. I posit that the more foreign aid recipients perceive a civil society organization as being, the less likely they will be to want to engage directly with it, although they may expect the organization itself to be better suited to bringing developments to their community. I test this theory using a conjoint survey experiment carried out on Malawian market vendors who are the target of a large-scale USAID intervention. The findings will have important implications for how foreign aid might impact citizen engagement in a way that has not been captured before.
registration_responses.q16: The more foreign an organization, the more likely an individual will be to assess the organization positively. At the same time, the more foreign an organization, the less likely an individual will be to express a desire to interact with that organization actively. An organization that is more foreign along multiple dimensions will seem particularly foreign to individuals, and therefore the interaction between different organization characteristics will sharpen the effects in the previous hypothesis. Individuals who are already in community organizations will be less likely to want to participate in more foreign organizations, and their evaluations of foreign organizations will be lower. Individuals who demonstrate apathy about their own role in achieving desirable outcomes because of the work that other, non-local organizations do on their behalf will as a whole be more ambivalent about engagement with organizations. These individuals will be more likely to see more foreign organizations as being of higher quality.
registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses will be tested via a conjoint survey experiment. Analysis of the conjoint will be done via logit and OLS. A causal ANOVA estimator developed by Egami and Imai (2018) will be used to test for interaction effects. Subgroup analysis based on respondents’ answers to two different survey questions will be done as well. Please see pre-analysis plan for more details.
registration_responses.q24: 18-2303; Office of Human Research Ethics – University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

attributes.title: How do Brazilian voters trade school quality and other government outputs when evaluating municipal politicians?

q1.value: How do Brazilian voters trade school quality and other government outputs when evaluating municipal politicians?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In a working paper (“Evaluating students and politicians: Test scores and electoral accountability in Brazil”), we find that voters who receive information about the performance of municipal schools are less likely to vote for the incumbent when such signals are positive than when they are negative. This goes against established theories of retrospective voting and electoral accountability. Our findings stem from two research designs and two datasets from Brazil. First, in a regression discontinuity design (RDD) exploiting data for the municipal elections of 2008, 2012 and 2016 across Brazil, we study the effect of municipalities meeting a highly visible school quality target (IDEB) on electoral outcomes. Second, in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) in a sample of municipalities in Pernambuco, we study the effect of informing voters before the election about their municipality’s rank in the performance in an early student assessment (ANA) on individual vote choice. Contrary to expectations, we find in both the RDD and the RCT that signals about school quality decrease, rather than increase, electoral support for the incumbent. In the RDD, we find that municipalities that meet the IDEB target have a lower vote share for the mayor than those that miss their target. In the RCT, we find that voters are less likely to vote for the mayor the better the performance of the municipal schools. We are conducting an online survey of Brazilian voters to understand what drives our counter-intuitive results.

q16.value: The main hypothesis stemming from the RCT and the RDD is that voters are less likely to vote for the incumbent when they receive positive signals about the quality of public schools (H1). The main goal of the survey is to explain this counter-intuitive finding. We have developed a number of hypotheses that could explain it: Trade-off hypotheses: H2: Education quality vs public jobs trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between the quality of schools and the number of people employed by the municipality (in education or other sectors) or, more generally, a trade-off between government performance and jobs. H3: Education quality vs healthcare quality trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between improving the quality of municipal schools and the quality of municipal clinics, which they value more. H4: Education quality vs poverty alleviation trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they perceive a trade-off between the quality of municipal schools and the municipal government’s efforts at reducing poverty, which they value more. H5: Education quality vs government responsiveness trade-off. Voters punish good performers because they see politicians who improve school quality as less responsive to their needs. Saliency hypotheses: H6: Education quality is seen as taking up government resources while not contributing to welfare. Voters punish good performers because they do not see education as relevant to their interests. H7: Parents reward school quality. Parents (H7a), parents of primary- and middle-school aged children (H7b), or parents of primary- and middle-school aged children enrolled in municipal schools (H7c) reward good performers because they see education as more relevant to their interests.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, we will conduct a short online survey with Brazilian respondents recruited via Facebook. The core of the survey is a vignette experiment. Before the vignette we will expose respondents to a battery of questions about how important they think different policy areas are for their personal interests. In particular, respondents will be asked about education, healthcare, employment in the municipal sector, economic development, security, and fight against poverty. This will allow us to (i) collect data about saliency of different policy areas for voters; and (ii) prime respondents to think about the importance of different policy areas, and thus simulate the conditions in which voters decide their vote during electoral campaigns. Immediately before the vignette, we will inform voters about IDEB (what it is and what it means for a municipality to meet its IDEB target), and ask them whether they had already heard about it. The vignette will be very similar to the one used in the RCT (Boas et al 2017) and in previous studies (Weitz-Shapiro and Winters 2017), focused on a hypothetical mayor. Respondents will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: positive treatment (where they are informed that the municipality met its school quality target), negative treatment (where they are informed that the municipality did not meet its school quality target), and control (where they are not given information about whether the municipality met its target). This design will allow us to identify the effect of positive vs negative information about the quality of schools, by comparing the mean of a given outcome in the positive treatment group to the mean of that same outcome in the negative treatment group. It will also allow us to identify the effect of school quality information versus absence thereof, by comparing the mean of a given outcome in the positive and negative treatment groups to the mean of that outcome in the placebo group. After the vignette, we will ask respondents about their likelihood of voting for that hypothetical mayor, on a 4-point Likert scale. This will provide additional tests for H1. Next, we will ask them about their perception of how likely they think the hypothetical mayor is to 1) have invested a lot of money in education, 2) have hired many municipal workers, 3) have improved municipal schools, 4) have improved municipal clinics, 5) have helped people like them solve their problems, and 6) have reduced poverty in the municipality.

attributes.title: Intergroup Mobilization in Divided Societies: A Field Experiment in Israel

q1.value: Intergroup Mobilization in Divided Societies: A Field Experiment in Israel

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Our study addresses existing gaps in the literature, by testing two strategies of mobilization for collective action in divide societies, which relate to (1) the identity of mobilizers, and (2) the type of appeals they make. We test both strategies through a field-experiment in Israel, aimed to mobilize members of an Israeli Jewish-Arab social movement to attend an annual convention. To do so, we collaborate with a local social movement on their e-mail information campaign. As part of the campaign, we randomize the identity of the sender as well as the type of appeal he/she makes, to learn whether mobilization is more effective when encouraged by a majority (minority) group member, and when sharing personal-sentimental (objective) content about the social movement and its upcoming event.

q16.value: Our quantities of interest relate to two treatment arms: 1. Mobilizer’s ethnic identity, 2. Type of appeal made by the mobilizer (and the interaction between both treatment arms). In addition, we consider the moderating effects of gender and ethnicity (of message receiver in relation to mobilizer). R code for estimating these effects is presented in the attached per-analysis plan.

q17.value: After block randomizing subjects into treatment conditions, based on the key outcome of interest measured at baseline, we employ OLS models to test our hypotheses. R code for estimating these our models can be found in our pre-analysis plan. Since some of our outcomes are binary, we will test the robustness of our results with logit models.

q27.value: The intervention is implemented by our collaborating organization, Standing Together.
